text:
I don't really know what happens, but that what I've been instructed to do so far.

I think you simply can't onboard a new node with the previous party hint id, otherwise the network will not accept the new onboarding.

The node identifier can be the same (arguably should be called node name, instead of identifier), if I understand it correctly.

Maybe <@U03HMUTQ5F0> can clarify

elements.text:

text:
Hello, Im currently improving our monitoring for our validator, we do not use prometheus operators so cant utilise service monitors. Though the <https://docs.dev.global.canton.network.sync.global/deployment/observability/metrics.html#enabling-metrics|docs>:
> Alternatively you can add prometheus scrape annotations to the charts that are configured to scrape port 10013.
Splice <https://github.com/digital-asset/decentralized-canton-sync/blob/v0.3.21/cluster/helm/splice-participant/templates/participant.yaml#L87C1-L89C24|Participant Helm chart> is configured for this but validator deployment <https://github.com/digital-asset/decentralized-canton-sync/blob/v0.3.21/cluster/helm/splice-validator/templates/validator.yaml#L265-L268|does not expose this port> and the service <https://github.com/digital-asset/decentralized-canton-sync/blob/v0.3.21/cluster/helm/splice-validator/templates/validator.yaml#L350-L355|does not allow for annotations>. Can this be amended or can I put a pull request in for this?

elements.text: Hello, Im currently improving our monitoring for our validator, we do not use prometheus operators so cant utilise service monitors. Though the
docs
Alternatively you can add prometheus scrape annotations to the charts that are configured to scrape port 10013.
Splice
Participant Helm chart
is configured for this but validator deployment
does not expose this port
and the service
does not allow for annotations
. Can this be amended or can I put a pull request in for this?

text: `ports` on pod serves informational purpose only. The port is exposed on the service <https://github.com/digital-asset/decentralized-canton-sync/blob/a6c4a7cd181b68fd70080ac8c4407ed4be1819fd/cluster/helm/splice-validator/templates/validator.yaml#L363-L364> ~L265-L268~

elements.text: ports
on pod serves informational purpose only. The port is exposed on the service

text: discovery by prometheus is implemented by means of ServiceMonitor CRD

elements.text: discovery by prometheus is implemented by means of ServiceMonitor CRD

text: <https://github.com/digital-asset/decentralized-canton-sync/blob/a6c4a7cd181b68fd70080ac8c4407ed4be1819fd/cluster/helm/splice-validator/templates/serviceMonitor.yaml#L5C16-L5C23>

If the reason to choose docker compose is to have a relatively lightweight setup without having to maintain full-fledged Kubernetes then some zero-ops Kubernetes (like MicroK8s) could be a good option as well

elements.text: If the reason to choose docker compose is to have a relatively lightweight setup without having to maintain full-fledged Kubernetes then some zero-ops Kubernetes (like MicroK8s) could be a good option as well

text:
We're trying to deploy the Canton Utility DAR as documented on here: <https://docs.utility.canton.network.digitalasset.com/doc/daml-api/html/canton-utility-setup/utility-setup.html#deploy>

On the document it say deploy v0.3.5.

On JFROG, I also see 0.5.0 version so I want to check what is the stable dar version I should install to our validator.

elements.text: We're trying to deploy the Canton Utility DAR as documented on here:

On the document it say deploy v0.3.5.

On JFROG, I also see 0.5.0 version so I want to check what is the stable dar version I should install to our validator.
